Empires & Puzzles Abigail Review: The Mad Photographer

Is Abigail a snapshot of brilliance or an overexposed disaster? We analyze this controversial Secret Hero, her risky Insanity mechanics, and whether her Xulu minions are worth the mental breakdown in the current Empires & Puzzles meta.
Abigail Review: Developing Insanity One Snap at a Time
Abigail is a 5-star Fire hero from the
family, originally released in May 2024 as a "Secret Hero" within the Shadow Summon. She brings a unique, albeit risky, playstyle centered around the
mechanic. While most heroes try to avoid madness, Abigail embraces it—literally bathing herself in it to fuel her defensive capabilities.

She operates as an Average speed support-attacker hybrid, dealing damage to all enemies while summoning minions that spread madness and bleeding wounds. However, her reputation has been... complicated. Often cited by the community as one of the more underwhelming "Secret" heroes, she occupies a niche that balances high risk with moderate reward. She doesn't have a costume, so what you see is what you get: a photographer who might just snap and attack her own team if you aren't careful.

Abigail’s design is a striking mix of Victorian-era investigative journalism and Eldritch horror. She stands poised with a quill and a notepad, looking somewhat frazzled, with a massive, steampunk-esque camera strapped to her. The red spirits swirling around her quill suggest that her writing might be influenced by forces beyond mortal comprehension. It’s a thematic home run for the "Investigator" family—she looks exactly like someone who read a book she shouldn't have and is now frantically documenting the end of the world.
As of late 2025, Abigail's base stats (1139 Attack, 1163 Defense, 2033 Health) show clear signs of aging when compared to the modern heavyweights.
Significantly lower than modern attackers like
(1328). She lacks the raw punch to be a primary damage dealer.
Her bulk is decent but no longer elite. Newer tanks and supports push 1300+ Defense and 2400+ Health easily.
At 1133 base power, she sits well below the 1260+ standard of the newest releases.
While she isn't "paper thin," she relies heavily on emblems, limit breaks, and her family bonus to survive in a meta dominated by heroes who hit significantly harder than she does.
Abigail's special skill is a double-edged sword wrapped in a riddle.
260% to all at Average speed is "okay" but not game-changing. It serves more to soften targets than to wipe them.
These are the core of her kit. They inherit 15% HP and 20% Attack. Originally criticized for being too weak (at 10%), the bump to 15% helps, but they are still relatively fragile meat shields.
Each minion hit inflicts Bleed and
on the target. This is a slow burn. If you can keep the minions alive, they can slowly drive the enemy team mad, causing them to attack their own allies or skip turns.
The kicker is that Abigail inflicts

on herself instantly. This pushes her over halfway to "fully insane" (100) in a single cast. This interacts with her passive (discussed below) but also puts her at immediate risk of malfunction if she isn't managed correctly.
Average. She needs 10 tiles to fire. Without innate mana boosting passives, she relies on troops and team support to speed up.
With ~1139 base attack (before troops/LB), a 260% hit deals roughly
raw damage spread across 5 enemies (before defense reduction). This is essentially a "tickle" in the current meta of boosted health and massive defense stats.
With ~2033 base HP, a 15% minion has roughly
. A single slash attack or incidental AoE from a modern defender will likely vaporize them.
. It stacks with the minion hits, but it's negligible against modern healing.
Casting once puts her at 55/100. A second cast without healing (which reduces insanity) puts her at 100+, guaranteeing negative effects.
Family Bonus, Passives, Aether Power & Unique Abilities

family bonus provides a boost to Attack and Health (20%/30%/40% for 1/2/3 heroes). This is a solid stat stick that helps patch up her aging stats, especially if you can pair her with other strong investigators.
This is the most interesting part of her kit. She gains
After one cast (55 Insanity), she effectively has
This turns her self-inflicted madness into a massive survival tool. She becomes incredibly tanky
she fires, which is ironic because she might also become useless if she goes fully insane.
is a practical, if boring, choice. It synergizes with her passive damage reduction to make her very hard to kill with tile damage or snipes.

Upon release, Abigail was widely panned as one of the "worst" Secret Heroes. Players felt her minions were too weak, her speed too slow, and the risk of self-insanity too high for the payout. She didn't redefine the meta like some of her peers.

Time has not been kind. Her damage percentage (260%) is now what we expect from Fast or Very Fast heroes, not Average ones. Her stats have fallen behind significantly. The Insanity mechanic, while unique, is too slow to impact modern Rush wars or fast-paced raids effectively.

. She is not a top-tier defender or attacker. Her best use case is in very specific PvE scenarios or war attacks where you can control the flow of battle and utilize her damage reduction to use her as a "bait" tank, though even that is a stretch. She is primarily a collector's trophy.
Maximizes her minion HP (making them harder to kill) and synergizes with her damage reduction passive to make her an absolute brick.
Her special skill damage becomes even less relevant.
Squeezes every drop of damage out of her AoE hit and minion strikes.
Minions die faster; she dies faster before her passive ramps up.
. Abigail's only hope of being useful is staying alive long enough for her minions to stack insanity on the enemy. A dead photographer takes no pictures.
Once she casts, the damage reduction passive makes her very sturdy.
If minions stick, they passively increase enemy Insanity, potentially disrupting their offensive flow without you doing anything.
Summons a meat shield for the whole team.
55 Self-Insanity is a massive liability. You are essentially debuffing your own hero significantly.
260% damage at Average speed is underwhelming in 2025.
Even at 15%, the minions are easily cleared by almost any modern AoE hero.
To manage her Insanity, she requires constant healing (which reduces Insanity counters), forcing you to build the team around her maintenance.
Minions provide pseudo-health, and bleed bypasses defense, but her self-insanity is risky without healing to cleanse it. Actually, you can't heal in Bloody Battle, so her Insanity will never go down.
Long battles allow her to stack insanity on bosses.
A serviceable hero for your 4th or 5th war team against passive defenses.
Essential. Healing reduces Insanity. You need healers who fire often or provide HoT to keep her sanity in check.
A Taunter can protect her minions, allowing them to hit more often and spread more Insanity.
Healer (e.g., Hathor) - Abigail - Taunter (e.g., Phorcys) - Sniper - Healer.
Double healers ensure her Insanity bar is constantly scrubbed, allowing her to fire multiple times without losing control.
Overwhelm the enemy with minions. If Abigail's minions are protected by other minion buffs, they survive longer to inflict bleed and madness.
Heroes that destroy/replace minions make Abigail useless.
Heroes like Xiaotu disable minion effects or punish summoning.
Anyone who deals extra damage to minions (e.g., Grimble, Ogima) will eat her lunch.

If you pulled Abigail early, she is a solid 5-star simply because she hits everyone and gives you minions. The Insanity mechanic might be confusing, but at lower levels, the raw stats of a 5-star (even an older one) are helpful. Just bring a healer with her always.

or Alpha Aethers unless you are a collector or purely F2P with no other options. There are 4-star heroes released in late 2025 (like glass costumes) that arguably offer more utility or damage with less risk. She is a fun toy, not a war machine.
The community was… not kind to Abigail.
"Probably the worst secret hero and my first secret hero... they all can’t be winners."
"I don’t really trust any of the insanity heroes to be effective on defense. After the first cast… 1/2 the time they are going to punch themselves in the face."
"Much more relevant in attack with a taunter than in defense. That insanity will keep stacking."
Many players were baffled by her average speed and low damage compared to contemporaries like Atwood or the Goblins. She is widely considered the "dud" of the Secret summon pool.

Abigail is a hero with a fascinating concept—a journalist driving herself mad to get the story (and damage reduction)—trapped in a kit that feels under-tuned for the modern era. Her mechanic requires too much maintenance for too little payoff. While her artwork is top-tier and her damage reduction is funny to watch in action, she usually ends up being more trouble than she's worth.
A unique curiosity best left on the bench unless you enjoy living dangerously.
